Celebrating International Womenâ€™s Day

By Hannah Boyle

Orla McAndrew reflects on this important day and speaks to other editors and writers about who inspires them

The Movements: Pop Art

Irony, parody and mass culture decorate the altar of this style, while modernism, 'elitist' art and any subculture that takes itself too seriously lies ripped to shreds by its discerning and satirical tone

Leeds: The Real Fashion Deal

So you love fashion and take care in your appearance. You read the latest glossy magazine and religiously follow the trends, or even create the trends because you are that cool. Everything about you screams style

Putting Sex back into Sex

It's time to have some fun, but do you think Chlamydia is the name of a flower...

The Cycling Accessory - the sexy way to save the planet and your time

If you are a fresher, you are a student of the cycling revolution. Boris may have started it off in the capital, but the rest of the country has seen a creeping trend in two-wheeled travel

Hungry? A blitzed kitchen guide

Here is the basic kitchen cupboard to help you get started with cooking at University. It's not supposed to be a Marmite selection (foods you love or hate), just a stock pile of simple ingredients that you'll use everyday for most dishes (Thumbnail credit Your typical student kitchen...)

THE York Venue Guide

It's hard to ignore the pitying look or anecdote of some vague relative's stag-do when admitting you've just committed yourself to at least three years of frolicking in the cobbles of York

Fashion at York

One of the most iconic films of our generation once stated "On Wednesdays we wear pink!" But now fresher ladies and gentlemen is the day in which you graduate from high school/sixth form fashion rules

Jake & Dinos Chapman

Brothers Jake and Dinos Chapman have an exhibition currently spread across both of White Cube's London galleries. Shock here has the ability to expose, rather than simply create an aesthetic reaction.

The Inbetweeners Movie

This summer we join the nation's favourite incompetent teenagers on their quest to Malia for "sex, booze, tits, sex, fanny, minge . . . sex, tits, booze and . . . sex".

Rise of the Planet of the Apes

What has consistently made the <em>Planet of the Apes</em> films so fascinating is of course the inclusion of apes. Not necessarily because they scream and shout and make other amusing guttural noises; or because they wield a supra-human strength and are capable of smashing shit up, but more due to the fact that they so closely resemble us human beings.

Arrietty

<em>Arrietty</em> doesn't represent the first time that the much loved Studio Ghibli has dabbled in the art of adaptation. <em>Howl's Moving Castle</em>, and <em>Ponyo</em> both finding their original source material in the work of established children's authors.

The Riots: Fashion goes from riches to rags

The riots have shown no mercy to both high street shops and high fashion stores alike. Although there is no question that the riots have affected a range of businesses across the retail spectrum it is evident that larger stores such as Debenhams will be able to recover in time whereas smaller independent stores may have to close their doors forever

Last Night

The new Keira Knightley film verges on being similar to Closer staring Jude Law, but is more concise in its delivery. Paris Bennett lifts the lid on this unfortunately overlooked 90-minute film. Rating: ****

Edinburgh Fringe '11: Where to eat

By James Bithell

Whether you're performing or watching, the Fringe is a big one, and cafes will feel like a godsend in between shows. Mia de Graaf gives you her pick of pizza places, chocolate soup cafes, and hog roast rolls in Edinburgh this year (Thumbnail credit A Kilimanjaro coffee. Image: alixanaeuphoria via Flickr)

Lucian Freud dies aged 88

Celebrated German-British artist Lucian Freud has died aged 88 in his London home (Thumbnail credit Lucian Freud: Self Portrait, Reflection [2002]. Image: freeparking via Flickr)

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2

It is the end of Harry Potter. This film makes it go out with a bang, a smile, a tear. Yates has seen us through the end admirably well, even though he hasn't always tapped into the rich story in his hands with bold depth

Band of the Week: Big Star

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

The Importance of Being Earnest

<em>The Importance of Being Earnest</em> is a fine production to end the year on; it should be recommended to those who have not seen the play before, yet it still offers something to those already familiar with the script

Not seen. Not heard.

With the the first UN-recognised International Widows Day on Thursday 23rd June, Mia de Graaf investigates the invisible existence of the world's women in mourning (Thumbnail credit A widow from Vrindavan. Indian widows are conventionally expected to wear white.)

Faking the Fight

By James Bithell

Talking to the people behind World Wrestling Entertainment Camilla Apcar finds out why watching fake fights is better than the real deal (Thumbnail credit The Wrestling stars perform to the crowds at events across the United States)

Life in Plastic

By James Bithell

Art very literally comes in all shapes and sizes, as Paris Bennett discovers talking to conceptual artist Pandemonia (Thumbnail credit Pandemonia in her many guises. All photos credit: Pandemonia)

The Sperm Trade

How would you feel if your father was "Mystery Masturbator 150?" Sophie Walker investigates

Ethical Fashion

By James Bithell

Ethical clothing is reputedly incompatible with style. Hannah Clugston doesn't agree (Thumbnail credit Model Lucy Dixon wears a selection of ethical clothes from ONE Boutique and Deep. Photos: Peter Iveson)

Paul Theroux

By James Bithell

Hannah Ellis-Petersen talks to Paul Theroux at the Hay Literary Festival on the alluring relationship between travel and fiction

Highlights of Hay Literary Festival

By James Bithell

Gilbert & George, Taryn Simon & Simon Baker, and Rob Lowe

Down The Road

Lyndon Ashmore checked out the up and coming philosophy festival nearby: How The Light Gets In

A Friendship Facialised

By James Bithell

Photographer John Minihan talks to Sarah Jilani about his latest exhibition, his friendship with Samuel Beckett, and the stories that live behind the image (Thumbnail credit All photos: John Minihan)

In Pictures: Travel Photography

By James Bithell

Summer and travel are practically synonymous for many; we take look at inspiring travel photos that can get anyone reaching for their backpack

Broccoli Trees

By James Bithell

Emily Heggadon investigates artists creating artwork solely in the medium of food

Editor's Picks

Oscar Wilde's 1895 comedy, <strong>The Importance of Being Earnest</strong> in Week 9 finishes off a diverse and successful summer term at the Barn...
